The analysis of the actual scene in relation to “Beauty and the Beast” though reveals juxtapositions rather than parallels. On one hand we have Sansa being escorted to the Sept at sword-point and Tyrion recognizing that he should have handled the “proposal” differently. On the other hand we have Beauty showing up for dinner (not the actual wedding) on her own volition, with no threats or coercion involved and the Beast proposing to her, but in no way imposing this marriage on her by making the decision for her, or presenting it to her as a fait accompli, the way Tyrion did.

Furthermore, when the Beast proposed, he fully expected Beauty’s refusal and he was prepared to respect her decision and try again the next day. When Sansa spoke against this marriage in front of Tyrion though, in the very beginning of the scene, he didn’t stop the ceremony, nor did he resolve to try again the day after. On the contrary, he tried to coerce Sansa into marrying him right on that instant, basically telling her she was getting married to a Lannister that day one way or another.

Some would say that Tyrion did offer Sansa a way out, but did he really? Considering the talk Tyrion had with his father and uncle before the wedding, Lancel was not an option and all that speculation between Tywin and Kevan on who would become Sansa’s husband instead of him was just a byplay for his benefit and not actual options. Even if it was an actual choice, Sansa would still have had to take a Lannister husband that day and she didn’t want to marry any Lannister, no matter how comely he was. So she resigned to her fate, “consenting” to the marriage, because, obviously, saying “no” was not an option. This of course is once again juxtaposed with Belle, to whom Beast gave all the power and agency to decide for her fate and whose wish not to take the Beast as her husband was respected throughout the film.

At this point I believe it is important to note that in the original “Beauty and the Beast” fairytale the Beast didn’t ask for Beauty’s hand in marriage, but rather for her to come into his bed:

Suddenly the Beast asked her if she would allow him to sleep with her.

At this unexpected request, all Beauty’s fears were revived. She uttered a terrible shriek, and exclaimed, in spite of herself, “Oh! Heavens, I am lost!”

“Have no fear,” the Beast quietly replied; “but without frightening yourself, answer me properly: say precisely yes or no!”

Trembling, Beauty answered, “No, Beast.”

“Well then, since you will not let me,” returned the docile creature, “I shall leave you. Good-night, Beauty.”

“Good-night, Beast,” said the frightened maiden, much relieved.

Beauty and the Beast by Gabrielle-Suzanne Barbot de Villenueve (translation from french)

GRRM seems to follow both versions simultaneously in this storyline with Sansa and Tyrion, considering Tyrion forced Sansa both into marriage and into sex, stopping only at the last minute before initiating intercourse.

What is rather interesting is that it wasn’t Sansa who said she wouldn’t sleep with him, but Tyrion himself:

When he hopped up on the bed and put his hand on her breast, Sansa could not help but shudder. She lay with her eyes closed, every muscle tense, dreading what might come next. Would he touch her again? Kiss her? Should she open her legs for him now? She did not know what was expected of her.

“Sansa.” The hand was gone. “Open your eyes.”

She had promised to obey; she opened her eyes. He was sitting by her feet, naked. Where his legs joined, his man’s staff poked up stiff and hard from a thicket of coarse yellow hair, but it was the only thing about him that was straight.

“My lady,” Tyrion said, “you are lovely, make no mistake, but… I cannot do this. My father be damned. We will wait. The turn of a moon, a year, a season, however long it takes. Until you have come to know me better, and perhaps to trust me a little.” His smile might have been meant to be reassuring, but without a nose it only made him look more grotesque and sinister.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

Sansa’s obedience despite her lack of consent is to be attributed to the fact that Tyrion himself had already made it more than clear that she had no say in the matter:

“I am,” the Imp confessed, “but not so drunk that I cannot attend to my own bedding.” He hopped down from the dais and grabbed Sansa roughly. “Come, wife, time to smash your portcullis. I want to play come-into-the-castle.”

Red-faced, Sansa went with him from the Small Hall. What choice do I have? Tyrion waddled when he walked, especially when he walked as quickly as he did now. The gods were merciful, and neither Joffrey nor any of the others moved to follow.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

“I am your husband. You can take off your armor now.”

“And my clothing?”

“That too.” He waved his wine cup at her. “My lord father has commanded me to consummate this marriage.”

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

When he finally realized that she had no answer for him, Tyrion Lannister drained the last of his wine. “I understand,” he said bitterly. “Get in the bed, Sansa. We need to do our duty.”

She climbed onto the featherbed, conscious of his stare. A scented beeswax candle burned on the bedside table and rose petals had been strewn between the sheets. She had started to pull up a blanket to cover herself when she heard him say, “No.”

The cold made her shiver, but she obeyed.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

In all of the above passages Tyrion is the one giving the orders and Sansa the one obeying them, knowing she has no other choice but sleep with him. And that is because Tyrion himself doesn’t present her with the option to say no; something that establishes him as a foil to the Beast. Yes, he does have a change of heart at the last moment due to his crisis of conscience, but that does not negate all the things he said and did before that. And the fact that it is ultimately Tyrion who decides that there would be no consummation and not Sansa, inverts the power dynamics of the original fairytale and erases the sovereignty of Sansa’s consent.

Now, back to the comparison between Cocteau’s film and ASOIAF, we see that the time Sansa and Tyrion spend together as husband and wife/prisoner is cut short, due to Sansa’s escape from King’s Landing to go to her “father” (Littlefinger is not Sansa’s real father, but he fills that role anyway).

Sansa’s escape takes place during a feast she attends with Tyrion, while she is dressed in a silver and purple gown and wearing her “amethyst” hairnet. This is a callback to the following scene in “Beauty and the Beast”:

Beauty is in the great hall, walking up and down in front of the fire. She is wearing a dark velvet dress. The marble busts at each end of the mantlepiece turn their heads to watch her. The clock strikes half past seven. Beauty looks up at the clock and sees the Beast’s reflection in the mirror above it.  She turns round as he walks across the room.

BEAUTY: How late you are!

THE BEAST: Thank you, Beauty, for noticing.

BEAUTY: Yes, I was awaiting you with great impatience, Beast.

She throws herself to her knees and grabs his cloak.

BEAUTY: I must talk to you!

THE BEAST (shocked): Beauty! Beauty!

BEAUTY (still on her knees, pleading): I cannot live another day without seeing my father again. Please let me go, I beg you!

THE BEAST: Stand up, Beauty, stand up.

He pulls her to her feet and leads her to a chair. He sits down beside her.

THE BEAST: I should be on my knees taking orders from you.

BEAUTY (almost in tears): Let me go. I promise to return.

THE BEAST: And when you return, will you be my wife?

BEAUTY (in despair): You’re torturing me.

THE BEAST: I know I’m repulsive. But I would die of heartbreak if I let you go and you took advantage of your freedom never to return.

BEAUTY: I’d come back in a week’s time. I respect you too much to cause your death.

The Beast lowers his head. Beauty strokes it.

THE BEAST (looking up at her): You coax me as though I were an animal.

BEAUTY (gently): But you are an animal.

THE BEAST: Your request is a very serious matter. I must think about it.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

In this scene the Beast shows up late for dinner and Beauty falls to her knees before him and begs him to let her go back to her father. The Beast despairs at her request and tells her he will think of it and a few days later, he visits her chambers and makes up his mind:

Beauty is lying on the bed. The Beast walks over to the foot of the bed.

THE BEAST: Beauty, are you ill?

BEAUTY: Yes, Beast. I am.

THE BEAST: What ails you?

BEAUTY: I know my father’s dying.

THE BEAST: I can’t bear to see you waste away.

BEAUTY: Send me home to my father.

THE BEAST: If I agree, will you promise to return in a week’s time, to the very day?

BEAUTY (smiling at him): I promise.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

When he sees her sorrow at having to stay away from her dying father, he relents and lets her go under the condition that she will return to him. He puts his faith in her, despite knowing he will die if she doesn’t keep her word, because her wellbeing and happiness is more important to him than his own.

Tyrion sees Sansa’s sorrow before the feast too, but instead of making him want to let her go, it made him want to trap her in another castle instead:

Their litter had been sitting in the sun, and it was very warm inside the curtains. As they lurched into motion, Tyrion reclined on an elbow while Sansa sat staring at her hands. She is just as comely as the Tyrell girl. Her hair was a rich autumn auburn, her eyes a deep Tully blue. Grief had given her a haunted, vulnerable look; if anything, it had only made her more beautiful. He wanted to reach her, to break through the armor of her courtesy. Was that what made him speak? Or just the need to distract himself from the fullness in his bladder?

“I had been thinking that when the roads are safe again, we might journey to Casterly Rock.” Far from Joffrey and my sister. The more he thought about what Joff had done to Lives of Four Kings, the more it troubled him. There was a message there, oh yes. “It would please me to show you the Golden Gallery and the Lion’s Mouth, and the Hall of Heroes where Jaime and I played as boys. You can hear thunder from below where the sea comes in …”

She raised her head slowly. He knew what she was seeing; the swollen brutish brow, the raw stump of his nose, his crooked pink scar and mismatched eyes. Her own eyes were big and blue and empty. “I shall go wherever my lord husband wishes.”

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion VIII

And he was provided with a chance to let Sansa go right after that, but he didn’t take it, choosing to change the subject instead:

Lady Olenna smiled. “I am pleased to say I shall be leaving for Highgarden the day after next. I have had quite enough of this smelly city, thank you. Perhaps you would like to accompany me for a little visit, whilst the men are off having their war? I shall miss my Margaery so dreadfully, and all her lovely ladies. Your company would be such sweet solace.”

“You are too kind, my lady,” said Sansa, “but my place is with my lord husband.”

Lady Olenna gave Tyrion a wrinkled, toothless smile. “Oh? Forgive a silly old woman, my lord, I did not mean to steal your lovely wife. I assumed you would be off leading a Lannister host against some wicked foe.”

“A host of dragons and stags. The master of coin must remain at court to see that all the armies are paid for.”

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion VIII

Sansa, just like Beauty, had longed to return to her family ever since she became a prisoner of the Lannisters. Considering the circumstances though, it would have been death to utter such a wish to anyone in court, much less her Lannister husband to whom she got married against her will. Still, Tyrion had guessed she wanted to be free, as demonstrated in the following quotes:

“Lord Stark asked for his sisters and his father’s sword as well,” Ser Cleos reminded him.

Ser Ilyn Payne stood mute, the hilt of Eddard Stark’s greatsword rising over one shoulder. “Ice,” said Tyrion. “He’ll have that when he makes his peace with us, not before.”

“As you say. And his sisters?”

Tyrion glanced toward Sansa, and felt a stab of pity as he said, “Until such time as he frees my brother Jaime, unharmed, they shall remain here as hostages. How well they are treated depends on him.” And if the gods are good, Bywater will find Arya alive, before Robb learns she’s gone missing.

A Clash of Kings - Tyrion VI

Tyrion rubbed at the raw stub of his nose. The scar tissue itched abominably sometimes. “His Grace the royal pustule has made Sansa’s life a misery since the day her father died, and now that she is finally rid of Joffrey you propose to marry her to me. That seems singularly cruel. Even for you, Father.”

[…]

“If your purpose here is to keep her from the Tyrells, why not return her to her mother? Perhaps that would convince Robb Stark to bend the knee.”

[…]

“You shall never have Casterly Rock, I promise you. But wed Sansa Stark, and it is just possible that you might win Winterfell.”

Tyrion Lannister, Lord Protector of Winterfell. The prospect gave him a queer chill.

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion III

Yet, even though Tyrion was keenly aware of Sansa’s predicament and had guessed that she would want to leave and go back to her family, instead of releasing her like he had promised, he put even more chains on her:

“Gone?” He looked startled. “Dead? Oh, Mother, no, not that, they haven’t harmed her, not that way, only… a bird came last night, but I couldn’t bring myself to tell you, not until your father was sent to his rest.” Robb took her hand. “They married her to Tyrion Lannister.”

Catelyn’s fingers clutched at his. “The Imp.”

“Yes.”

“He swore to trade her for his brother,” she said numbly. “Sansa and Arya both. We would have them back if we returned his precious Jaime, he swore it before the whole court. How could he marry her, after saying that in sight of gods and men?”

A Storm of Swords - Catelyn IV

The fact that Sansa had to resort to escaping from the Red Keep in secret, without asking for Tyrion’s permission stems from his own inability to cast his Lannister loyalties aside and do right by her by letting her go, as demonstrated in the above quotes. This once again is meant to accentuate how different Tyrion is from Cocteau’s Beast in that regard, putting his own fears before Sansa’s needs and happiness.

Despite Tyrion not giving her his permission to leave, Sansa leaves him anyway. And since Tyrion is not the one to release her, she leaves with no strings attached. This of course means that since Tyrion never made her promise him she would return, as the Beast had, Sansa never came back for him, even though she knew he was facing capital punishment.

This development in my opinion is GRRM’s in-text critique of the Stockholm syndrome usually associated with the more modernized version of the tale of “Beauty and the Beast” that has been established after the Disney film came out.

Beauty and the Beast is often accused of supporting a “Stockholm Syndrome” romance. In reality, it reflects what arranged marriages were often like at the time, and the Beast is much kinder than husbands had to be. Disney’s film updates the story for a modern audience, but it does so problematically. The drama of the original story was drawn from Beauty discovering that things are not always as they appear while Disney’s drama is drawn from Belle taming Beast.

The Evolution of Beauty and the Beast

As established on the first part of this meta, Sansa’s arc could very well be the result of GRRM’s grievances with Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast” adaptation, which actually has Belle fall in love with the Beast due to Stockholm syndrome and not because he’s being kind and respectful of her like in the original fairytale.

Tyrion was not as cruel as Joffrey or as vicious as the Hound, but he was a foil to Cocteau’s Beast nevertheless. And in order to demonstrate how Tyrion was not worthy of Sansa’s love, GRRM never had Sansa fall in love with him or care for him enough to go back and save him, subverting the very problematic Stockholm Syndrome romance trope Disney established.

Once more I’d like to thank @lostlittlesatellites and @kellyvela who have made the writing of this meta possible with their wonderful ideas and their constant support.
trail.content:
The first four parts of this meta series (part 1, part 2, part 3, part 4) have been an analysis of how GRRM has set up Sansa as the Beauty figure of ASOIAF and how Sandor Clegane and Joffrey Baratheon have served as foils to Cocteau’s Beast in Sansa’s storyline.

The third and final “Beast” figure GRRM has used in Sansa’s arc is none other than Tyrion Lannister. Tyrion is a much less obvious foil of the Beast, because both his appearance and his character align well with Cocteau’s Beast up until ASOS, where he was still toeing the line between hero and villain. Despite that, after analyzing the scenes Tyrion and Sansa have together, it becomes apparent that the dynamic between them is meant to be juxtaposed with the one between Beauty and the Beast and not paralleled.

Since this gets rather lengthy, the rest can be read under the cut.

There is no better chapter to showcase this than the one where Sansa and Tyrion get married, which bears a striking resemblance to the scene of the first dinner the Beast and Beauty share. Even before the actual wedding, GRRM establishes a connection between the two scenes by having Sansa and Beauty dressed in a similar way as we see below:

In the great hall the clock strikes seven. On each side of the blazing fire the marble busts turn their heads. Beauty is sitting at the table, wearing a dark jeweled dress, with matching jewels round her neck and wound into her hair. The hand from the candelabra on the table picks up the silver wine decanter to serve her. She leans back in her chair with a sigh of despair and closes her eyes. The door opens behind her and the Beast crosses the room. He stands behind her, leaning on the back of the chair.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

Cersei herself arrived with the seamstress, and watched as they dressed Sansa in her new clothes. The smallclothes were all silk, but the gown itself was ivory samite and cloth-of-silver, and lined with silvery satin. The points of the long dagged sleeves almost touched the ground when she lowered her arms. And it was a woman’s gown, not a little girl’s, there was no doubt of that. The bodice was slashed in front almost to her belly, the deep vee covered over with a panel of ornate Myrish lace in dove-grey. The skirts were long and full, the waist so tight that Sansa had to hold her breath as they laced her into it. They brought her new shoes as well, slippers of soft grey doeskin that hugged her feet like lovers.

[…]

Queen Cersei studied her critically. “A few gems, I think. The moonstones Joffrey gave her.”

“At once, Your Grace,” her maid replied.

When the moonstones hung from Sansa’s ears and about her neck, the queen nodded.

[…]

“The cloak,” she commanded, and the women brought it out: a long cloak of white velvet heavy with pearls. A fierce direwolf was embroidered upon it in silver thread. Sansa looked at it with sudden dread. “Your father’s colors,” said Cersei, as they fastened it about her neck with a slender silver chain.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

Both Sansa and Beauty are dressed in jeweled dresses and wear a necklace and a hairnet that matches the outfit. What’s interesting is that despite those similarities there is an inversion of color, considering Beauty wears a dark gown and Sansa a white one, which, from the very beginning sets the tone for the subversion to follow.

This subversion becomes obvious not only by examining the context of the Sansa/Tyrion scene, but also by the reverse order in which GRRM put the Sansa/Tyrion scenes in comparison to the “Beauty and the Beast” one.

The beginning of the dialogue in the Beauty and the Beast scene goes as follows:

THE BEAST: Don’t be afraid.

BEAUTY (summoning up all her courage): I … I won’t be afraid.

THE BEAST: Beauty, do you mind if I watch you while you dine?

BEAUTY: You are the master.

BEAST: No, I’m not.

(He pauses for a moment.)

There is no master here but you.

(He moves around to the side of the chair.)

I revolt you; you must find me very ugly.

BEAUTY: I cannot lie, Beast.

THE BEAST: Is everything here to your liking?

BEAUTY: I feel uneasy dressed in such finery, nor am I used to being waited upon.But I know you’re doing your utmost to help me forget your ugliness.

THE BEAST (walking over to the fireplace): My heart is kind, but I am a monster.

BEAUTY: Many men are more monstrous than you, but they hide it well.

THE BEAST: Besides my ugliness, I am lacking in wit.

BEAUTY: You have wit enough to realize it.

THE BEAST: Everything in this castle is yours. Your every whim will be fulfilled.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

Before the dialogue begins, the Beast uses his magic to serve her some wine (as you can read in the introduction of the scene) and the first thing he does is try to soothe her fear. When she tells him she will not be afraid of him, he asks for her consent to watch her do something as commonplace as dine. After that the Beast leads the conversation to his ugliness, about which Beauty refuses to lie and then he proceeds to talk about his virtue (his kindness) and his faults (his ugliness and his lack in wit).

The above dialogue was the thing that inspired the scene Sansa and Tyrion Lannister share in “their” bedroom after their wedding:

For their wedding night, they had been granted the use of an airy bedchamber high in the Tower of the Hand. Tyrion kicked the door shut behind them. “There is a flagon of good Arbor gold on the sideboard, Sansa. Will you be so kind as to pour me a cup?”

[…]

“I am your husband. You can take off your armor now.”

“And my clothing?”

“That too.” He waved his wine cup at her. “My lord father has commanded me to consummate this marriage.”

Her hands trembled as she began fumbling at her clothes. She had ten thumbs instead of fingers, and all of them were broken. Yet somehow she managed the laces and buttons, and her cloak and gown and girdle and undersilk slid to the floor, until finally she was stepping out of her smallclothes. Gooseprickles covered her arms and legs. She kept her eyes on the floor, too shy to look at him, but when she was done she glanced up and found him staring. There was hunger in his green eye, it seemed to her, and fury in the black. Sansa did not know which scared her more.

“You’re a child,” he said.

She covered her breasts with her hands. “I’ve flowered.”

“A child,” he repeated, “but I want you. Does that frighten you, Sansa?”

“Yes.”

“Me as well. I know I am ugly -

“No, my -if

He pushed himself to his feet. “Don’t lie, Sansa. I am malformed, scarred, and small, but…” she could see him groping “… abed, when the candles are blown out, I am made no worse than other men. In the dark, I am the Knight of Flowers.” He took a draught of wine. “I am generous. Loyal to those who are loyal to me. I’ve proven I’m no craven. And I am cleverer than most, surely wits count for something. I can even be kind. Kindness is not a habit with us Lannisters, I fear, but I know I have some somewhere. I could be… I could be good to you.”

[…]

When he finally realized that she had no answer for him, Tyrion Lannister drained the last of his wine. “I understand,” he said bitterly. “Get in the bed, Sansa. We need to do our duty.”

She climbed onto the featherbed, conscious of his stare. A scented beeswax candle burned on the bedside table and rose petals had been strewn between the sheets. She had started to pull up a blanket to cover herself when she heard him say, “No.”

The cold made her shiver, but she obeyed.

[…]

“On my honor as a Lannister,” the Imp said, “I will not touch you until you want me to.”

It took all the courage that was in her to look in those mismatched eyes and say, “And if I never want you to, my lord?”

His mouth jerked as if she had slapped him. “Never?”

Her neck was so tight she could scarcely nod.

“Why,” he said, “that is why the gods made whores for imps like me.” He closed his short blunt fingers into a fist, and climbed down off the bed.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

The subversive tone set up earlier, while Sansa was dressing for the wedding continues the bedroom scene, by having Tyrion ask Sansa to pour him the wine instead of serving her himself like the Beast did using his magic. After a bit of conversation unrelated to this analysis, Tyrion orders Sansa to undress. When she follows his instructions Tyrion stands there and watches her perform this intimate act without asking for her consent, which comes in direct opposition to what the Beast did, which was ask for Beauty’s consent to watch her eat.

After that, the discussion between them follows the same themes as the one between Beauty and the Beast but the vibe each of them gives off is very different. The first thing the Beast tells Beauty is “Do not be afraid” to assure her that she is safe from him. Instead of soothing Sansa’s fear though, the first thing Tyrion does is to intensify it with his confession that he lusts after her even though he sees she is just a child and then asks her whether he’s frightening her with that admission. Sansa in turn replies that she is indeed afraid of Tyrion, unlike Beauty, who said she would not be afraid of the Beast. This of course is to be expected, considering Tyrion did threaten Sansa with marital rape when the Beast never threatened Beauty in any way.

The moment Sansa admits her fear would have been ideal for Tyrion to try and comfort her by telling her she had nothing to fear from him, but instead of that, he steers the conversation away from Sansa’s fear and towards himself and his own “fear” of lusting after a child, exhibiting a rather alarming disregard of Sansa’s feelings.

After that, Tyrion starts talking about his appearance, stating, like the Beast, that he knows that Sansa finds him ugly. Beauty replied that she could not lie to the Beast about it, but Sansa, already terrified, does try to lie to Tyrion, in order to protect herself from his impending (as far as she knows) wrath. Tyrion then goes on to talk about his fault (his ugliness) and his virtues (his generosity, his bravery, his cleverness and his kindness).

At first glance, his little speech resembles the one the Beast makes, but on closer inspection they prove to be opposites, because the Beast focuses on his faults, offering only one virtue, when Tyrion focuses on his virtues, giving Sansa only one fault. In essence, the Beast was selling himself short, making no attempts to endear himself to Beauty before asking her to marry him, when on the other hand Tyrion was overselling himself, trying to become more desirable in her eyes to convince her to have sex with him.

This is a very important part of the subversion, because, as has already been analyzed in the first part of this meta series, in the “Beauty and the Beast” adaptations that follow the themes of Villenueve’s original one (like Cocteau’s), Beauty must know exactly what she’s getting herself into before agreeing to marry the Beast. That means that the Beast (or in other cases Beauty’s father) must lay all his cards on the table and not try to endear himself to Beauty through pretty words.

Tyrion though, not only tries to make himself appear more desirable in her eyes through that little speech, but also gives it to Sansa after the marriage proposal and not before, like the Beast is supposed to. This inverse order, as mentioned above, ties into the subversion too, as it is meant to showcase how Tyrion is the Beast’s foil that does everything backwards.

As mentioned above, after the Beast talks about himself to Belle, he asks her to marry him. We can see that in the rest of the “Beauty and the Beast” dinner scene cited below:

THE BEAST (walking back to the dining table): I shall appear every evening at seven. Before leaving I shall ask you a question; it will always be the same one.

BEAUTY: What is your question?

THE BEAST: Beauty, will you be my wife?

BEAUTY: No, Beast.

THE BEAST: Farewell then, Beauty. Until tomorrow.

He leaves the room.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

The ending of the scene is very straightforward. The Beast informs Beauty that he will be asking her a question every day. That question is whether Beauty will be his wife. When she tells him no, he respects her answer and leaves, promising to ask again the next day.

This sequence I believe is meant to be juxtaposed with the one right before Sansa and Tyrion’s wedding:

His face darkened. “I am. I’m your father, and I can marry you to whoever I like. To anyone. You’ll marry the pig boy if I say so, and bed down with him in the sty.” His green eyes glittered with amusement. “Or maybe I should give you to Ilyn Payne, would you like him better?”

Her heart lurched. “Please, Your Grace,” she begged. “If you ever loved me even a little bit, don’t make me marry your−”

“−uncle?”Tyrion wore a doublet of black velvet covered with golden scrollwork, thigh-high boots that added three inches to his height, a chain of rubies and lions’ heads. But the gash across his face was raw and red, and his nose was a hideous scab. “You are very beautiful, Sansa,” he told her.

“It is good of you to say so, my lord.” She did not know what else to say. Should I tell him he is handsome? He’ll think me a fool or a liar. She lowered her gaze and held her tongue.

“My lady, this is no way to bring you to your wedding. I am sorry for that. And for making this so sudden, and so secret. My lord father felt it necessary, for reasons of state. Else I would have come to you sooner, as I wished.” He waddled closer. “You did not ask for this marriage, I know. No more than I did. If I had refused you, however, they would have wed you to my cousin Lancel. Perhaps you would prefer that. He is nearer your age, and fairer to look upon. If that is your wish, say so, and I will end this farce.”

I don’t want any Lannister, she wanted to say. I want Willas, I want Highgarden and the puppies and the barge, and sons named Eddard and Bran and Rickon. But then she remembered what Dontos had told her in the godswood. Tyrell or Lannister, it makes no matter, it’s not me they want, only my claim. “You are kind, my lord,” she said, defeated. “I am a ward of the throne and my duty is to marry as the king commands.”

He studied her with his mismatched eyes. “I know I am not the sort of husband young girls dream of, Sansa,” he said softly, “but neither am I Joffrey.”

“No,” she said. “You were kind to me. I remember.”

Tyrion offered her a thick, blunt-fingered hand. “Come, then. Let us do our duty.”

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

This scene seems to continue from where the “previous” one ended, where Sansa and Tyrion were talking about beauty and Sansa contemplated on whether she should lie about Tyrion’s ugliness, and then moves on to the marriage part of the rest of the “Beauty and the Beast” scene.

The analysis of the actual scene in relation to “Beauty and the Beast” though reveals juxtapositions rather than parallels. On one hand we have Sansa being escorted to the Sept at sword-point and Tyrion recognizing that he should have handled the “proposal” differently. On the other hand we have Beauty showing up for dinner (not the actual wedding) on her own volition, with no threats or coercion involved and the Beast proposing to her, but in no way imposing this marriage on her by making the decision for her, or presenting it to her as a fait accompli, the way Tyrion did.

Furthermore, when the Beast proposed, he fully expected Beauty’s refusal and he was prepared to respect her decision and try again the next day. When Sansa spoke against this marriage in front of Tyrion though, in the very beginning of the scene, he didn’t stop the ceremony, nor did he resolve to try again the day after. On the contrary, he tried to coerce Sansa into marrying him right on that instant, basically telling her she was getting married to a Lannister that day one way or another.

Some would say that Tyrion did offer Sansa a way out, but did he really? Considering the talk Tyrion had with his father and uncle before the wedding, Lancel was not an option and all that speculation between Tywin and Kevan on who would become Sansa’s husband instead of him was just a byplay for his benefit and not actual options. Even if it was an actual choice, Sansa would still have had to take a Lannister husband that day and she didn’t want to marry any Lannister, no matter how comely he was. So she resigned to her fate, “consenting” to the marriage, because, obviously, saying “no” was not an option. This of course is once again juxtaposed with Belle, to whom Beast gave all the power and agency to decide for her fate and whose wish not to take the Beast as her husband was respected throughout the film.

At this point I believe it is important to note that in the original “Beauty and the Beast” fairytale the Beast didn’t ask for Beauty’s hand in marriage, but rather for her to come into his bed:

Suddenly the Beast asked her if she would allow him to sleep with her.

At this unexpected request, all Beauty’s fears were revived. She uttered a terrible shriek, and exclaimed, in spite of herself, “Oh! Heavens, I am lost!”

“Have no fear,” the Beast quietly replied; “but without frightening yourself, answer me properly: say precisely yes or no!”

Trembling, Beauty answered, “No, Beast.”

“Well then, since you will not let me,” returned the docile creature, “I shall leave you. Good-night, Beauty.”

“Good-night, Beast,” said the frightened maiden, much relieved.

Beauty and the Beast by Gabrielle-Suzanne Barbot de Villenueve (translation from french)

GRRM seems to follow both versions simultaneously in this storyline with Sansa and Tyrion, considering Tyrion forced Sansa both into marriage and into sex, stopping only at the last minute before initiating intercourse.

What is rather interesting is that it wasn’t Sansa who said she wouldn’t sleep with him, but Tyrion himself:

When he hopped up on the bed and put his hand on her breast, Sansa could not help but shudder. She lay with her eyes closed, every muscle tense, dreading what might come next. Would he touch her again? Kiss her? Should she open her legs for him now? She did not know what was expected of her.

“Sansa.” The hand was gone. “Open your eyes.”

She had promised to obey; she opened her eyes. He was sitting by her feet, naked. Where his legs joined, his man’s staff poked up stiff and hard from a thicket of coarse yellow hair, but it was the only thing about him that was straight.

“My lady,” Tyrion said, “you are lovely, make no mistake, but… I cannot do this. My father be damned. We will wait. The turn of a moon, a year, a season, however long it takes. Until you have come to know me better, and perhaps to trust me a little.” His smile might have been meant to be reassuring, but without a nose it only made him look more grotesque and sinister.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

Sansa’s obedience despite her lack of consent is to be attributed to the fact that Tyrion himself had already made it more than clear that she had no say in the matter:

“I am,” the Imp confessed, “but not so drunk that I cannot attend to my own bedding.” He hopped down from the dais and grabbed Sansa roughly. “Come, wife, time to smash your portcullis. I want to play come-into-the-castle.”

Red-faced, Sansa went with him from the Small Hall. What choice do I have? Tyrion waddled when he walked, especially when he walked as quickly as he did now. The gods were merciful, and neither Joffrey nor any of the others moved to follow.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

“I am your husband. You can take off your armor now.”

“And my clothing?”

“That too.” He waved his wine cup at her. “My lord father has commanded me to consummate this marriage.”

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

When he finally realized that she had no answer for him, Tyrion Lannister drained the last of his wine. “I understand,” he said bitterly. “Get in the bed, Sansa. We need to do our duty.”

She climbed onto the featherbed, conscious of his stare. A scented beeswax candle burned on the bedside table and rose petals had been strewn between the sheets. She had started to pull up a blanket to cover herself when she heard him say, “No.”

The cold made her shiver, but she obeyed.

A Storm of Swords - Sansa III

In all of the above passages Tyrion is the one giving the orders and Sansa the one obeying them, knowing she has no other choice but sleep with him. And that is because Tyrion himself doesn’t present her with the option to say no; something that establishes him as a foil to the Beast. Yes, he does have a change of heart at the last moment due to his crisis of conscience, but that does not negate all the things he said and did before that. And the fact that it is ultimately Tyrion who decides that there would be no consummation and not Sansa, inverts the power dynamics of the original fairytale and erases the sovereignty of Sansa’s consent.

Now, back to the comparison between Cocteau’s film and ASOIAF, we see that the time Sansa and Tyrion spend together as husband and wife/prisoner is cut short, due to Sansa’s escape from King’s Landing to go to her “father” (Littlefinger is not Sansa’s real father, but he fills that role anyway).

Sansa’s escape takes place during a feast she attends with Tyrion, while she is dressed in a silver and purple gown and wearing her “amethyst” hairnet. This is a callback to the following scene in “Beauty and the Beast”:

Beauty is in the great hall, walking up and down in front of the fire. She is wearing a dark velvet dress. The marble busts at each end of the mantlepiece turn their heads to watch her. The clock strikes half past seven. Beauty looks up at the clock and sees the Beast’s reflection in the mirror above it.  She turns round as he walks across the room.

BEAUTY: How late you are!

THE BEAST: Thank you, Beauty, for noticing.

BEAUTY: Yes, I was awaiting you with great impatience, Beast.

She throws herself to her knees and grabs his cloak.

BEAUTY: I must talk to you!

THE BEAST (shocked): Beauty! Beauty!

BEAUTY (still on her knees, pleading): I cannot live another day without seeing my father again. Please let me go, I beg you!

THE BEAST: Stand up, Beauty, stand up.

He pulls her to her feet and leads her to a chair. He sits down beside her.

THE BEAST: I should be on my knees taking orders from you.

BEAUTY (almost in tears): Let me go. I promise to return.

THE BEAST: And when you return, will you be my wife?

BEAUTY (in despair): You’re torturing me.

THE BEAST: I know I’m repulsive. But I would die of heartbreak if I let you go and you took advantage of your freedom never to return.

BEAUTY: I’d come back in a week’s time. I respect you too much to cause your death.

The Beast lowers his head. Beauty strokes it.

THE BEAST (looking up at her): You coax me as though I were an animal.

BEAUTY (gently): But you are an animal.

THE BEAST: Your request is a very serious matter. I must think about it.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

In this scene the Beast shows up late for dinner and Beauty falls to her knees before him and begs him to let her go back to her father. The Beast despairs at her request and tells her he will think of it and a few days later, he visits her chambers and makes up his mind:

Beauty is lying on the bed. The Beast walks over to the foot of the bed.

THE BEAST: Beauty, are you ill?

BEAUTY: Yes, Beast. I am.

THE BEAST: What ails you?

BEAUTY: I know my father’s dying.

THE BEAST: I can’t bear to see you waste away.

BEAUTY: Send me home to my father.

THE BEAST: If I agree, will you promise to return in a week’s time, to the very day?

BEAUTY (smiling at him): I promise.

La Belle et la Bête (Beauty and the Beast) script

When he sees her sorrow at having to stay away from her dying father, he relents and lets her go under the condition that she will return to him. He puts his faith in her, despite knowing he will die if she doesn’t keep her word, because her wellbeing and happiness is more important to him than his own.

Tyrion sees Sansa’s sorrow before the feast too, but instead of making him want to let her go, it made him want to trap her in another castle instead:

Their litter had been sitting in the sun, and it was very warm inside the curtains. As they lurched into motion, Tyrion reclined on an elbow while Sansa sat staring at her hands. She is just as comely as the Tyrell girl. Her hair was a rich autumn auburn, her eyes a deep Tully blue. Grief had given her a haunted, vulnerable look; if anything, it had only made her more beautiful. He wanted to reach her, to break through the armor of her courtesy. Was that what made him speak? Or just the need to distract himself from the fullness in his bladder?

“I had been thinking that when the roads are safe again, we might journey to Casterly Rock.” Far from Joffrey and my sister. The more he thought about what Joff had done to Lives of Four Kings, the more it troubled him. There was a message there, oh yes. “It would please me to show you the Golden Gallery and the Lion’s Mouth, and the Hall of Heroes where Jaime and I played as boys. You can hear thunder from below where the sea comes in …”

She raised her head slowly. He knew what she was seeing; the swollen brutish brow, the raw stump of his nose, his crooked pink scar and mismatched eyes. Her own eyes were big and blue and empty. “I shall go wherever my lord husband wishes.”

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion VIII

And he was provided with a chance to let Sansa go right after that, but he didn’t take it, choosing to change the subject instead:

Lady Olenna smiled. “I am pleased to say I shall be leaving for Highgarden the day after next. I have had quite enough of this smelly city, thank you. Perhaps you would like to accompany me for a little visit, whilst the men are off having their war? I shall miss my Margaery so dreadfully, and all her lovely ladies. Your company would be such sweet solace.”

“You are too kind, my lady,” said Sansa, “but my place is with my lord husband.”

Lady Olenna gave Tyrion a wrinkled, toothless smile. “Oh? Forgive a silly old woman, my lord, I did not mean to steal your lovely wife. I assumed you would be off leading a Lannister host against some wicked foe.”

“A host of dragons and stags. The master of coin must remain at court to see that all the armies are paid for.”

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion VIII

Sansa, just like Beauty, had longed to return to her family ever since she became a prisoner of the Lannisters. Considering the circumstances though, it would have been death to utter such a wish to anyone in court, much less her Lannister husband to whom she got married against her will. Still, Tyrion had guessed she wanted to be free, as demonstrated in the following quotes:

“Lord Stark asked for his sisters and his father’s sword as well,” Ser Cleos reminded him.

Ser Ilyn Payne stood mute, the hilt of Eddard Stark’s greatsword rising over one shoulder. “Ice,” said Tyrion. “He’ll have that when he makes his peace with us, not before.”

“As you say. And his sisters?”

Tyrion glanced toward Sansa, and felt a stab of pity as he said, “Until such time as he frees my brother Jaime, unharmed, they shall remain here as hostages. How well they are treated depends on him.” And if the gods are good, Bywater will find Arya alive, before Robb learns she’s gone missing.

A Clash of Kings - Tyrion VI

Tyrion rubbed at the raw stub of his nose. The scar tissue itched abominably sometimes. “His Grace the royal pustule has made Sansa’s life a misery since the day her father died, and now that she is finally rid of Joffrey you propose to marry her to me. That seems singularly cruel. Even for you, Father.”

[…]

“If your purpose here is to keep her from the Tyrells, why not return her to her mother? Perhaps that would convince Robb Stark to bend the knee.”

[…]

“You shall never have Casterly Rock, I promise you. But wed Sansa Stark, and it is just possible that you might win Winterfell.”

Tyrion Lannister, Lord Protector of Winterfell. The prospect gave him a queer chill.

A Storm of Swords - Tyrion III

Yet, even though Tyrion was keenly aware of Sansa’s predicament and had guessed that she would want to leave and go back to her family, instead of releasing her like he had promised, he put even more chains on her:

“Gone?” He looked startled. “Dead? Oh, Mother, no, not that, they haven’t harmed her, not that way, only… a bird came last night, but I couldn’t bring myself to tell you, not until your father was sent to his rest.” Robb took her hand. “They married her to Tyrion Lannister.”

Catelyn’s fingers clutched at his. “The Imp.”

“Yes.”

“He swore to trade her for his brother,” she said numbly. “Sansa and Arya both. We would have them back if we returned his precious Jaime, he swore it before the whole court. How could he marry her, after saying that in sight of gods and men?”

A Storm of Swords - Catelyn IV

The fact that Sansa had to resort to escaping from the Red Keep in secret, without asking for Tyrion’s permission stems from his own inability to cast his Lannister loyalties aside and do right by her by letting her go, as demonstrated in the above quotes. This once again is meant to accentuate how different Tyrion is from Cocteau’s Beast in that regard, putting his own fears before Sansa’s needs and happiness.

Despite Tyrion not giving her his permission to leave, Sansa leaves him anyway. And since Tyrion is not the one to release her, she leaves with no strings attached. This of course means that since Tyrion never made her promise him she would return, as the Beast had, Sansa never came back for him, even though she knew he was facing capital punishment.

This development in my opinion is GRRM’s in-text critique of the Stockholm syndrome usually associated with the more modernized version of the tale of “Beauty and the Beast” that has been established after the Disney film came out.

Beauty and the Beast is often accused of supporting a “Stockholm Syndrome” romance. In reality, it reflects what arranged marriages were often like at the time, and the Beast is much kinder than husbands had to be. Disney’s film updates the story for a modern audience, but it does so problematically. The drama of the original story was drawn from Beauty discovering that things are not always as they appear while Disney’s drama is drawn from Belle taming Beast.

The Evolution of Beauty and the Beast

As established on the first part of this meta, Sansa’s arc could very well be the result of GRRM’s grievances with Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast” adaptation, which actually has Belle fall in love with the Beast due to Stockholm syndrome and not because he’s being kind and respectful of her like in the original fairytale.

Tyrion was not as cruel as Joffrey or as vicious as the Hound, but he was a foil to Cocteau’s Beast nevertheless. And in order to demonstrate how Tyrion was not worthy of Sansa’s love, GRRM never had Sansa fall in love with him or care for him enough to go back and save him, subverting the very problematic Stockholm Syndrome romance trope Disney established.

Once more I’d like to thank @lostlittlesatellites and @kellyvela who have made the writing of this meta possible with their wonderful ideas and their constant support.
trail.content_abstract:
The first four parts of this meta series (part 1, part 2, part 3, part 4) have been an analysis of how GRRM has set up Sansa as the Beauty figure of ASOIAF and how Sandor Clegane and Joffrey Baratheon have served as foils to Cocteau’s Beast in Sansa’s storyline.

The third and final “Beast” figure GRRM has used in Sansa’s arc is none other than Tyrion Lannister. Tyrion is a much less obvious foil of the Beast, because both his appearance and his character align well with Cocteau’s Beast up until ASOS, where he was still toeing the line between hero and villain. Despite that, after analyzing the scenes Tyrion and Sansa have together, it becomes apparent that the dynamic between them is meant to be juxtaposed with the one between Beauty and the Beast and not paralleled.

Since this gets rather lengthy, the rest can be read under the cut.

summary: I have this weird mental image of Sansa and Arya creating a "My Favorite Murder" style true crime podcast in a modern...
body:
I have this weird mental image of Sansa and Arya creating a “My Favorite Murder” style true crime podcast in a modern au.

Y'know, to cope with all the shit they’ve been through, and to teach others how to avoid sociopaths.

summary: Apple has released a new batch of emoji. Of greatest interest to us in the GoT fandom is the one shown above which could serve...
caption:
Apple has released a new batch of emoji. Of greatest interest to us in the GoT fandom is the one shown above which could serve as a representation of a White Walker. 

There’s also a redhead who could be used for Sansa Stark.

True, they are not exactly identical to those characters. But then, how many emoji have you used to represent your mood which don’t look exactly like you? Who looks, for example, like this one?   😛

You can view the entire group of 70+ new emoji at Apple. They are apparently already included with the beta version of iOS 12.1 and will be part of the regular updates of all Mac systems.

title: HYSTERICAL: Chapter 2 of 5
body:
“The massage of the pelvic organs is a long and gentle procedure,” he soothes, as he washes his hands in warm water, as he brings the movable curtain around and divides her bodily this way. “A task that should only be entrusted to those alone who have clean hands and a pure heart.” He leans forward and lifts her skirts, and he hears the sharp inhale of breath but her body remains pliant. Their eyes meet over the curtain for the briefest of time.

“Miss Stone, I am a consummate professional and very highly experienced. Do you trust me?”

“I do, Maester.”

>>> READ CHAPTER 2
